document.title: History-Social Science Content Standards for California Public Schools, Kindergarten Through Grade Twelve

BD5B3600DFE40131003C68A86D17958E.description: Students understand the importance of individual action and character and explain how heroes from long ago and the recent past have made a difference in others' lives (e.g., from biographies of Abraham Lincoln, Louis Pasteur, Sitting Bull, George Washington Carver, Marie Curie, Albert Einstein, Golda Meir, Jackie Robinson, Sally Ride).

BD5AF140DFE40131003B68A86D17958E.description: Understand how limits on resources affect production and consumption (what to produce and what to consume).

BD5AB590DFE40131003A68A86D17958E.description: Understand the role and interdependence of buyers (consumers) and sellers (producers) of goods and services.

BD5A7920DFE40131003968A86D17958E.description: Describe food production and consumption long ago and today, including the roles of farmers, processors, distributors, weather, and land and water resources.

BD5A3A10DFE40131003868A86D17958E.description: Students understand basic economic concepts and their individual roles in the economy and demonstrate basic economic reasoning skills.

BD59EC40DFE40131003768A86D17958E.description: Describe the ways in which groups and nations interact with one another to try to resolve problems in such areas as trade, cultural contacts, treaties, diplomacy, and military force.

BD599DB0DFE40131003668A86D17958E.description: Explain how the United States and other countries make laws, carry out laws, determine whether laws have been violated, and punish wrongdoers.

BD593FA0DFE40131003568A86D17958E.description: Students explain governmental institutions and practices in the United States and other countries.

BD58F5B0DFE40131003468A86D17958E.description: Compare and contrast basic land use in urban, suburban, and rural environments in California.

BD58B3B0DFE40131003368A86D17958E.description: Locate on a map where their ancestors live(d), telling when the family moved to the local community and how and why they made the trip.

BD587110DFE40131003268A86D17958E.description: Label from memory a simple map of the North American continent, including the countries, oceans, Great Lakes, major rivers, and mountain ranges. Identify the essential map elements: title, legend, directional indicator, scale, and date.

BD582AE0DFE40131003168A86D17958E.description: Locate on a simple letter-number grid system the specific locations and geographic features in their neighborhood or community (e.g., map of the classroom, the school).

BD57DF70DFE40131003068A86D17958E.description: Students demonstrate map skills by describing the absolute and relative locations of people, places, and environments.

BD578CE0DFE40131002F68A86D17958E.description: Place important events in their lives in the order in which they occurred (e.g., on a time line or storyboard).

BD575250DFE40131002E68A86D17958E.description: Compare and contrast their daily lives with those of their parents, grandparents, and/or guardians.

BD571750DFE40131002D68A86D17958E.description: Trace the history of a family through the use of primary and secondary sources, including artifacts, photographs, interviews, and documents.

BD56D780DFE40131002C68A86D17958E.description: Students differentiate between things that happened long ago and things that happened yesterday.

BD565740DFE40131002A68A86D17958E.description: Students conduct cost-benefit analyses of historical and current events.

BD560E70DFE40131002968A86D17958E.description: Students identify and interpret the multiple causes and effects of historical events.

BD55C1B0DFE40131002868A86D17958E.description: Students identify the human and physical characteristics of the places they are studying and explain how those features form the unique character of those places.

BD558460DFE40131002768A86D17958E.description: Students summarize the key events of the era they are studying and explain the historical contexts of those events.

BD5506F0DFE40131002568A86D17958E.description: Students distinguish fact from fiction by comparing documentary sources on historical figures and events with fictionalized characters and events.

BD54C640DFE40131002468A86D17958E.description: Students pose relevant questions about events they encounter in historical documents, eyewitness accounts, oral histories, letters, diaries, artifacts, photographs, maps, artworks, and architecture.

BD548570DFE40131002368A86D17958E.description: Students differentiate between primary and secondary sources.

BD543CB0DFE40131002268A86D17958E.description: Research, Evidence, and Point of View

BD53F0B0DFE40131002168A86D17958E.description: Students judge the significance of the relative location of a place (e.g., proximity to a harbor, on trade routes) and analyze how relative advantages or disadvantages can change over time.

BD53AD70DFE40131002068A86D17958E.description: Students use map and globe skills to determine the absolute locations of places and interpret information available through a map's or globe's legend, scale, and symbolic representations.

BD5370E0DFE40131001F68A86D17958E.description: Students explain how the present is connected to the past, identifying both similarities and differences between the two, and how some things change over time and some things stay the same.

BD5333C0DFE40131001E68A86D17958E.description: Students correctly apply terms related to time, including past, present, future, decade, century, and generation.

BD52F5A0DFE40131001D68A86D17958E.description: Students place key events and people of the historical era they are studying in a chronological sequence and within a spatial context; they interpret time lines.

BD526C20DFE40131001B68A86D17958E.description: Historical and Social Sciences Analysis Skills
